SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: In paragraph 2, what does the phrase “a beautiful potpourri of differences” indicate about the author’s point of view?

A.Choice: The author believes traveling is miserable.

B.Choice: The author believes everyone has different opinions.

C.Choice: The author believes bus travel is superior to train travel.

D.Choice: The author believes her attitude toward travel is correct.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:. . . there is something about travel as a process that a wheels­up, wheels­down airplane ride d͟i͟l͟u͟t͟e͟s somewhat.
What does the word d͟i͟l͟u͟t͟e͟s mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: appeases

B.Choice: devalues

C.Choice: enhances

D.Choice: stresses

Content: Which quotation from paragraph 6 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “I don’t want to be all ‘modern conveniences have alienated us from the process of living’ about it, . . .”

B.Choice: “We can’t teleport, not yet, . . .”

C.Choice: “. . . a plane is the closest the average plebe is going to get right now.”

D.Choice: “. . . move from one place to another much faster than you’d otherwise be able to.”

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain- specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: In paragraph 6, the author says that “a plane is the closest the average p͟l͟e͟b͟e is going to get” to teleporting.
What does the word p͟l͟e͟b͟e mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: location

B.Choice: pace

C.Choice: person

D.Choice: vehicle

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: What does the comparison in paragraph 8 reveal about the author?

A.Choice: It shows the author believes riding a bus is efficient.

B.Choice: It shows the author believes riding a bus is economical.

C.Choice: It shows the author believes slowing down is beneficial.

D.Choice: It shows the author believes natural resources are necessary.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: How does paragraph 10 contribute to the development of a central idea?

A.Choice: It shows the author’s belief in folklore.

B.Choice: It shows the author’s appreciation for relaxation.

C.Choice: It shows the author’s use of the Internet while traveling.

D.Choice: It shows the author’s concern about being trapped in a vehicle.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: In paragraph 11, how does the author acknowledge and respond to a conflicting viewpoint?

A.Choice: by providing the details of train travel

B.Choice: by explaining the benefits of plane travel

C.Choice: by sharing that some people would not enjoy bus travel

D.Choice: by describing the negatives of eating snacks while traveling

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which quotation supports the author’s claim that riding a bus can be just as efficient as flying?

A.Choice: “. . . if you factor in the time you spend getting to the airport and going through security, you may end up breaking even.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “I don’t want to be all ‘modern conveniences have alienated us from the process of living’ about it, but there is something about travel as a process. . . .” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “So the vehicle feels a little outside of reality, especially if you’re traveling alone. It isolates and insulates you. . . .” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “And my personal worst travel woes have been plane and train­based— . . .” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: The narrator does not enjoy traveling because of crying babies.

B.Choice: The narrator enjoys traveling because she gets to visit new places.

C.Choice: The narrator does not enjoy traveling because she gets motion sickness.

D.Choice: The narrator enjoys traveling because it provides her time to do things she likes.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “This sort of me­time can be achieved on many forms of transportation— . . .” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “The scenery might blur around you, but you’re still touching the ground.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “. . . I’m hardly advocating we all spend three weeks on a ship dry heaving into the sea just to go to London. (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “And my personal worst travel woes have been plane and train­based— . . .” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: How does the figurative language in paragraph 11 impact the passage as a whole?

A.Choice: It explains Mowgli’s anger with the children.

B.Choice: It reveals Mowgli does not believe in superstitions.

C.Choice: It illustrates that Mowgli is fearful of living indoors.

D.Choice: It shows the loneliness Mowgli feels living in the village.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a literary text propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 1.
:ibox:“What is the good of a man . . . if he does not understand man’s talk? Now I am as silly and dumb as a man would be with us in the jungle. I must speak their talk.”
What do the sentences reveal about Mowgli?

A.Choice: Mowgli feels unhappy, but he is determined to succeed in the village of man.

B.Choice: Mowgli feels helpless living in the village of man and wants to return to the jungle.

C.Choice: Mowgli feels happy living in the village of man and wants to learn man’s language.

D.Choice: Mowgli feels angry, but he tries to learn their language to prove the villagers wrong.

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain- specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is the meaning of the phrase L͟a͟w͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟J͟u͟n͟g͟l͟e as it is used in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: the leader of the jungle

B.Choice: the jungle where laws are kept

C.Choice: the customs of the jungle animals

D.Choice: a rule book for animals in the jungle

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “It was not for fun that he had learned while he was with the wolves to imitate the challenge of bucks. . . .” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “. . . Mowgli hauled it out by the tail, and helped to stack the pots for their journey to the market. . . .” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “. . . the village head­man told Mowgli that he would have to go out with the buffaloes next day, . . .” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “Mowgli, who naturally knew something about what they were talking of, . . .” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 5.

:ibox:Then the little children in the village made him very angry. . . . only the knowledge that it was unsportsmanlike to kill little naked cubs kept him from picking them up and breaking them in two.
What does the author’s metaphor reveal about Mowgli’s feelings toward the little children?

A.Choice: Mowgli feels that the little children are acting immature.

B.Choice: Mowgli feels that the little children are small and unprotected.

C.Choice: Mowgli feels that the little children are angry and a waste of his time.

D.Choice: Mowgli feels that the little children are not playing fairly and are acting like bears.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read paragraph 6.
:ibox:He did not know his own strength in the least. In the jungle he knew he was weak compared with the beasts, but in the village people said that he was as strong as a bull.
How does the author’s use of figurative language impact the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: by showing that Mowgli acts like an animal because he was raised by wolves

B.Choice: by showing that the people in the village think Mowgli is very powerful for someone so young

C.Choice: by suggesting that the people in the village think that Mowgli is forceful and respect what he has to offer

D.Choice: by suggesting that Mowgli left the jungle because the beasts felt he was weak and lacked respect for him

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a literary text propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Which quotation from paragraph 7 explains why Mowgli is chosen over the other villagers to herd the buffalo?

A.Choice: “When the potter’s donkey slipped in the clay pit, Mowgli hauled it out by the tail, . . .”

B.Choice: “. . . Mowgli . . . helped to stack the pots for their journey to the market at Khanhiwara.”

C.Choice: “When the priest scolded him, Mowgli threatened to put him on the donkey too, . . .”

D.Choice: “. . . he went off to a circle that met every evening on a masonry platform. . . .”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 9.
:ibox:. . . his body was i͟n͟h͟a͟b͟i͟t͟e͟d by the ghost of a wicked, old money­lender, who had died some years ago.
Which word could replace i͟n͟h͟a͟b͟i͟t͟e͟d as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: birthed

B.Choice: created

C.Choice: demanded

D.Choice: occupied

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quotation supports the idea that Mowgli works hard to be successful in the village of man?

A.Choice: “It was not for fun that he had learned while he was with the wolves to imitate the challenge of bucks in the jungle and the grunt of the little wild pig.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “‘Remember he can never till now have slept on a bed. If he is indeed sent in the place of our son he will not run away.’” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “For three months after that night Mowgli hardly ever left the village gate, he was so busy learning the ways and customs of men.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “In the jungle he knew he was weak compared with the beasts, but in the village people said that he was as strong as a bull.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What does Mowgli know that Buldeo does not?

A.Choice: He knows the beast was a money­lender.

B.Choice: He knows the truth about the tale of the tiger.

C.Choice: He knows the cobweb was created by a spider.

D.Choice: He knows the tiger limped because it was injured.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Luckily, the Law of the Jungle had taught him to keep his temper, for in the jungle life and food depend on keeping your temper; . . .” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “It was the village club, and the head­man and the watchman and the barber, who knew all the gossip of the village, and old Buldeo, the village hunter, who had a Tower musket, met and smoked.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “Mowgli . . . had to cover his face not to show that he was laughing, . . .” (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: “Buldeo was speechless with surprise for a moment, and the head­man stared.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which statement represents a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Nature is superior to civilization.

B.Choice: Respect should be shown to elders.

C.Choice: Life is an adventure that should be enjoyed.

D.Choice: Conformity to a new situation can be difficult.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “‘What is the good of a man,’ he said to himself at last, ‘if he does not understand man’s talk?’” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “It was not for fun that he had learned while he was with the wolves to imitate the challenge of bucks in the jungle. . . .” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “Luckily, the Law of the Jungle had taught him to keep his temper, . . .” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “He did not know his own strength in the least.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 7.

:ibox:And Mowgli had not the faintest idea of the difference that c͟a͟s͟t͟e makes between man and man. When the potter’s donkey slipped in the clay pit, Mowgli hauled it out by the tail, and helped to stack the pots for their journey to the market at Khanhiwara. That was very shocking, too, for the potter is a low-c͟a͟s͟t͟e man, and his donkey is worse.
Which TWO descriptions mean the same as c͟a͟s͟t͟e as it is used in the sentences?

A.Choice: an occupation as a potter

B.Choice: an occupation as a farmer

C.Choice: a social ranking of animals and people

D.Choice: a physical ranking of animals and people

E.Choice: a group of people that share common cultural features

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: How does the author’s inclusion of the hyperbole “shocked the world” impact the tone of paragraph 1 of “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: It creates a serious tone.

B.Choice: It creates a regretful tone.

C.Choice: It creates an amazed tone.

D.Choice: It creates an energetic tone.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What inference can be made based on paragraph 4 of “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: People with tooth decay generally live shorter lives.

B.Choice: People of the farming era were not aware of tooth decay.

C.Choice: People with a poor diet may also have a shorter life span.

D.Choice: People of the non­farming era were concerned with dental hygiene.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The early farmers traded their good health, nutritious diets, and longer life span for shorter lives plagued by disease. . . .” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “. . . early farmers ate the same boring starches and sugars that came from their crops of corn, barley, wheat, or rice.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “The change in lifestyle and diet from pre­farming to farming is recorded in the archaeological record.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “Research on skeletal remains reveals that before farming Europeans had few problems with their teeth.” (paragraph 5)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Which quotation supports the claim that humans have paid a high price for the change in lifestyles in “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: “Didn’t farming end starvation and famine?” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “The change in lifestyle and diet from pre­farming to farming is recorded in the archaeological record.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “Wear patterns, scratch marks, and dental decay all tell a story about the foods we eat and how they were prepared.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “The most significant change in the teeth of early farming communities is the number and types of cavities.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Content: What is the author’s purpose for writing “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: to encourage readers to take better care of their teeth by making it a daily priority

B.Choice: to inform readers about the effect tooth decay has on the overall health of an individual

C.Choice: to explain that the diet that resulted from farming has contributed to an increase in tooth decay

D.Choice: to explain the harmful effects of sugar on the human body, as well as its role in increasing tooth decay

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which sentence summarizes a central idea in “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: The benefits of farming outweigh any possible negative effects.

B.Choice: Science and history reveal that diet strongly affects tooth decay.

C.Choice: The creation of refined sugar created worldwide health problems.

D.Choice: Tooth decay has decreased significantly since the prefarming era.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Didn’t farming end starvation and famine? Didn’t it free us from having to wander the land looking for our next meal?” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Wear patterns, scratch marks, and dental decay all tell a story about the foods we eat and how they were prepared.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “The most significant change in the teeth of early farming communities is the number and types of cavities.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “Certainly, we cannot go back to being nomads, but we can learn to eat nutritious diets and save our teeth.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Which THREE statements should be included in an accurate summary of “A Scratch Tells All”?

A.Choice: Finely ground bits of starches cause most cavities because they are trapped between teeth.

B.Choice: Consuming large amounts of meat and fat does not contribute to the decaying of tooth enamel.

C.Choice: People from the farming era had 50 percent more dental defects than people of the pre­farming era.

D.Choice: While farming has benefited society in many ways, its products have increased the rate of tooth decay.

E.Choice: Humans have made a costly mistake by consuming too much starch, leading to an increase in tooth decay.

F.Choice: Foods like nuts, berries, roots, and fruit are what pre-farmers ate; farmers ate corn, barley, wheat, and rice.

G.Choice: Research shows that across the world, the increase of farming also increased the percentage of tooth decay.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: Read paragraph 1 from “Hard Facts.”
:ibox:What’s more destructive to teeth than fire, extreme cold, or desert heat? Read on to find the answer.
How does the structure of the introduction relate to a central idea in the passage?

A.Choice: Description demonstrates the problems of tooth decay.

B.Choice: Comparison and contrast states the topic of tooth decay.

C.Choice: Question and answer helps lead in to the topic of tooth decay.

D.Choice: Statement of a problem suggests a solution to decrease tooth decay.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 2 of “Hard Facts.”
:ibox:Modern-day police often use teeth to help identify victims of accidents and f͟o͟u͟l play.
What does f͟o͟u͟l mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: wrongful

B.Choice: unpleasant

C.Choice: make certain

D.Choice: out-of-bounds

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 3 of “Hard Facts.”
:ibox:Teeth, however, are not indestructible. All are s͟u͟s͟c͟e͟p͟t͟i͟b͟l͟e to decay.
What does s͟u͟s͟c͟e͟p͟t͟i͟b͟l͟e mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: exposed

B.Choice: immune

C.Choice: numb

D.Choice: resistant

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.
Content: Which statement supports BOTH authors’ claims about how teeth are damaged?

A.Choice: Both Bryant and Simmons believe that fluoride helps prevent tooth decay.

B.Choice: Both Bryant and Simmons claim that sugars and carbohydrates support the formation of plaque.

C.Choice: Bryant believes buried skeletons reveal reasons for tooth decay, while Simmons believes teeth found in archaeological sites show reasons.

D.Choice: Bryant states that teeth are a useful guide to health and diet, while Simmons states that the police use teeth to help identify victims of accidents.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.
Content: How is the concept of tooth decay treated differently in the two passages?

A.Choice: In “A Scratch Tells All,” the author details the importance of taking care of one’s teeth; in “Hard Facts,” the author emphasizes the history of dental care.

B.Choice: In “A Scratch Tells All,” the author reveals the benefits of farming on oral hygiene; in “Hard Facts,” the author shows the importance of good oral hygiene.

C.Choice: In “A Scratch Tells All,” the author describes the need for early awareness of dental problems; in “Hard Facts,” the author describes the need for changes in dental practices.

D.Choice: In “A Scratch Tells All,” the author concentrates on the changes in agriculture and how they affect tooth decay; in “Hard Facts,” the author concentrates on the importance of good oral hygiene.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: How does the author create suspense in the beginning of the passage?

A.Choice: by allowing the reader to know Tom’s thoughts and actions

B.Choice: by allowing the reader to observe the salmon’s civility toward Tom

C.Choice: by allowing the reader to observe Tom’s interactions with the salmon

D.Choice: by allowing the reader to know some of the salmon’s feelings about Tom

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which quotation from paragraph 7 is figurative language showing Tom’s respect for the salmon?

A.Choice: “Such a fish!”

B.Choice: “. . . shining silver from head to tail, . . .”

C.Choice: “. . . with a grand hooked nose and grand curling lip, and a grand bright eye, . . .”

D.Choice: “Surely he must be the salmon, the king of all the fish.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 9.
:ibox:The salmon looked at him full in the face, and then went on without minding him, with a swish or two of his tail which made the stream b͟o͟i͟l again.
What is the meaning of b͟o͟i͟l as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: being vibrant

B.Choice: being turbulent

C.Choice: causing intense heat

D.Choice: causing small bubbles

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: Which TWO quotations from paragraph 25 show how the author creates suspense?

A.Choice: “‘. . . they are relations of ours. . . .’”

B.Choice: “‘. . . they were just like us: . . .’”

C.Choice: “‘. . . they were so lazy, and cowardly, and greedy, . . .’”

D.Choice: “‘. . . they are very properly punished for it; . . .’”

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quotation supports the idea that Tom should not be afraid of the salmon?

A.Choice: “‘. . . I shall surely lose my way, or some strange thing will bite me. I will stop here and look out for the otter, or the eels, or some one to tell me where I shall go.’” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “. . . silver from head to tail, and here and there a crimson dot; with a grand hooked nose and grand curling lip, and a grand bright eye, looking round him as proudly as a king, . . .” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “. . . for salmon are all true gentlemen, and, like true gentlemen, they look noble and proud enough, and yet, like true gentlemen, they never harm or quarrel with any one, . . .” (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: “‘. . . I see what you are, my little dear. I have met one or two creatures like you before, and found them very agreeable and well­behaved.’” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a literary text propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Which quotation reveals the salmon’s attitude toward trout?

A.Choice: “‘Ah?’ said the salmon, very stately but very civilly. ‘I really beg your pardon; I see what you are, my little dear.’” (paragraph 15)

B.Choice: “‘Indeed, it was only last night that one at the river’s mouth came and warned me and my wife of some new stake­nets which had got into the stream, . . .’” (paragraph 18)

C.Choice: “‘Were there no babies up this stream?’ asked the lady salmon.” (paragraph 20)

D.Choice: “‘My dear, we do not even mention them, if we can help it; . . .’” (paragraph 25)

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: How does the phrase “what low company!” in paragraph 22 affect the reader’s view of the trout?

A.Choice: The phrase indicates that trout are plain and ordinary.

B.Choice: The phrase characterizes the trout as an unacceptable associate.

C.Choice: The phrase highlights the connection between the trout and the salmon.

D.Choice: The phrase illustrates the trout as dull in contrast to the grandeur of the salmon.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze the extent to which a filmed or live production of a story or drama stays faithful to or departs from the text or script, evaluating the choices made by the director or actors.
Content: Which paragraphs do the pictures help the reader better understand?

A.Choice: paragraphs 6 and 14

B.Choice: paragraphs 7 and 25

C.Choice: paragraphs 8 and 9

D.Choice: paragraphs 16 and 17

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Analyze the extent to which a filmed or live production of a story or drama stays faithful to or departs from the text or script, evaluating the choices made by the director or actors.
Content: How do the pictures contribute to the passage?

A.Choice: They show how the trout got its name.

B.Choice: They show why Tom becomes a water baby.

C.Choice: They show how the salmon helped the trout.

D.Choice: They show the difference between the trout and the salmon.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Read the incomplete summary of The Water­Babies.

:ibox:Tom, a little boy who becomes a “water baby,” swims down the river to the sea. Tom meets some salmon, and they tell him they have met others like him in the sea. They also tell Tom that the trout are poorly mannered relatives of the salmon.
Which sentence should be added to make a complete and accurate summary?

A.Choice: Tom meets the largest salmon, whose companion is too tired to continue swimming upstream.

B.Choice: Tom finds a crack in a rock and waits for someone to tell him his way but eventually falls asleep.

C.Choice: Tom becomes frightened when he reaches the sea and decides to wait and ask someone what he should do.

D.Choice: Tom sees a proud salmon with a curling lip and bright eye that acts as if he is a king and tries to speak with him.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: In paragraphs 1 and 2, how does the author reveal the magnitude of the Great Molasses Flood in Boston?

A.Choice: by using problem and solution to show why molasses enveloped part of Boston

B.Choice: by using descriptive language to show how molasses enveloped part of Boston

C.Choice: by using cause and effect to show how molasses enveloped part of Boston

D.Choice: by using sequential order to show why molasses enveloped part of Boston

SubTopics: Analyze the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: How does the structure of paragraph 2 support the author’s purpose for including the paragraph in the passage?

A.Choice: The description details the initial problem in the passage.

B.Choice: The description determines how the plot of the passage was resolved.

C.Choice: The description explains the characters’ solution to the problem in the passage.

D.Choice: The description shows how different characters react to the same situation in the passage.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 5.
:ibox:From the open gash, a t͟s͟u͟n͟a͟m͟i of molasses gushed out at 35 miles an hour, overtaking trucks and wagons in its way.
What is the meaning of t͟s͟u͟n͟a͟m͟i as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: a useful amount

B.Choice: a measured amount

C.Choice: an unknown amount

D.Choice: an overwhelming amount

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What is the author attempting to emphasize in the passage when she uses the phrase “sending metal bolts zinging” in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: sounds

B.Choice: emotions

C.Choice: exaggerations

D.Choice: contradictions

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What is the meaning of b͟r͟i͟n͟e as it is used in paragraph 12?

A.Choice: a sticky syrup solution

B.Choice: a salt and water solution

C.Choice: a gooey molasses solution

D.Choice: a molasses and water solution

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: How does the author develop the idea that the molasses flood had long-lasting effects?

A.Choice: by illustrating the historical context

B.Choice: by providing accounts of the cleanup

C.Choice: by including the data about the disaster

D.Choice: by explaining the reasons for the disaster

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.
Content: What idea is reinforced by the photographs?

A.Choice: The city of Boston was very isolated.

B.Choice: The Boston people worked together to clean up the molasses.

C.Choice: The Boston area had extensive devastation from the molasses flood.

D.Choice: The city of Boston had a booming industry before the molasses flood.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.
Content: How do the photographs contribute to the reader’s understanding of the passage?

A.Choice: They inform the reader about molasses.

B.Choice: They supply information about railroad tracks.

C.Choice: They give additional information about Boston.

D.Choice: They provide historical context about the event.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: The author of the passage implies that the molasses flood devastated the city of Boston.
How does the author develop this central idea over the course of the passage?

A.Choice: by describing the initial event in detail

B.Choice: by explaining the recovery efforts of the authorities

C.Choice: by explaining the effects of the flood on the citizens

D.Choice: by describing the problems the flood caused for merchants

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an accurate summary of the text based upon this analysis.
Content: Which statement should be included in an accurate summary of the passage?

A.Choice: The tank held 2.3 million gallons of molasses.

B.Choice: The salt water cleaned up the molasses most effectively.

C.Choice: Mrs. Bridget Clougherty was killed by the great wave of molasses.

D.Choice: It was hard to rescue people due to the difficulty navigating through the molasses.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Content: Read the following prompt and write your complete response in the space provided.

:ibox:You have read “Noah Count and the Arkansas Ark,” a passage about a young man who learns a valuable lesson from his family members. Write an essay explaining how the author demonstrates the value of education and how the narrator’s point of view regarding his family’s lack of education changes over the course of the story. Use specific examples and details from the passage to support your response.

Your writing will be scored based on the development of ideas, organization of writing, and language conventions of grammar, usage, and mechanics.
Write your response for the prompt on the lines below.
